As far as I understand it, it's actually not the Doppler Effect, causing the red shift in distant star light.
For the Doppler Effect to take place, the observed object itself has to move towards or away from you.
But in case of the red shift, it's not that the stars themselves are moving away from us (or at all), but space expanding between them and us.
Not only is this expansion increasing the distance between those stars and us, but it is also stretching/elongating the lightwaves travelling through this expanding space. And herein lies the difference between elongation of wavelengths by the Doppler Effect and the red shift of the stars.

the fainter stars can be seen and, as the hours pass, the stellar groups rise from the eastern horizon,
reach their maximum altitude like the Sun, then set or become dim and invisible as daylight returns.

attached is strong, especially when it is seen that there are many stars in a particular region of the sky
that revolve, never rising, never setting, about a hub or pivot. These stars are said to be circumpolar.
It is then clear that those other stars that rise and set do so simply because their circular paths about
this pole are so big that they intersect the horizon.
The Moon also revolves across this upturned bowl. Although the Moon appears to have an angular
motion across the sky similar to that of the stars, careful observation over a few hours reveals that it
moves slightly eastwards relative to the star background.

The reason we cannot see the "dark" sky at night and why empty space appears black is much simpler than you have made out here. We cannot see anything unless light bounces off that thing or is emitted by that thing. Space is literally saturated with light - but we see space as black because that light isn't bouncing off anything in all that emptiness. The light that does manage to find something to bounce off of is simply not enough for us to see it. (Which is why we cannot see small or very distant objects in the sky - not enough photons bouncing off and then making it to our eyeballs) If there is nothing there to reflect or directly emit light, our eyes literally cannot see it. The sky appears blue during the day because the light hitting our eyes has been scattered (read: bounced) off the particles in the atmosphere. At night that same thing is occurring - there's just nowhere near enough light for us to still see a blue sky. There are not enough photons bouncing around for us to perceive the sky as blue anymore, so instead we see it as really super dark blue (not true black). Redshift doesn't explain it.  Stars emit energy along the entire electro-magnetic spectrum.  Red shifting means the entire spectrum shifts to the red (longer wavelength) direction, so what was EMITTED in the visible spectrum is now in the infrared (or longer) region but what was emitted in the ultraviolet (or x-ray) spectrum would be shifted to be visible light.

I belive the sky is dark because stars are far away & space isn't empty.  Light intensity falls off as a factor of distance squared (twice as far = 1/4 as bright, 10x as far = 1/100th as bright).   The eye can only see down to a certain level of luminosity.  This is why telescopes are big & can see stars not visible to the naked eye - they can concentrate more photons from a given place and see things too dim for unaided vision.

Another factor is that things get in the way and absorb the light from distant stars.  For every light emitting star there's a non-luminescent gas cloud just waiting to absorb that light.  There are also random molecules, rogue planets, planetoids, dead stars, etc. that can also block some of it.  This is one of the reasons astronomers use the entire electro-magnetic spectrum to study the sky:  regular (visible light) telescopes, radio telescopes, infrared telescopes, etc.  Some frequencies are better than others at passing through these obstacles, plus some things that absorb visible light will then radiate on the infrared spectrum.

The Doppler Effect is not what is at play here. This is because the Doppler effect dictates that objects are moving away from each other, which is true in space, but it's not the main cause of the redshift. The major cause is called a Cosmological Redshift, which means that instead of one or both objects moving away from the other, the expansion of space is causing the objects to be pushed away from each other. Think about the Doppler shift as you standing by a racetrack and watching a racecar go by at 300 mph. While the Cosmological Redshift is more like gluing buttons to a balloon and then blowing it up and watching them get stretched away from each other.

The actual answer is the human eye can only perceive a very small, narrow band of the electromagnetic spectrum called "the visible spectrum". 

We are basically "blind' for every wave length above and below the visible spectrum. Those wavelength are usually expressed in nanometers (nm). Our eyes can only "detect" light with wavelength between 390 and 700 nm, but the entire spectrum span a mind boggling 10^-21 nm (gamma rays) to 1 million nm (infra red) !!

Doppler effect 

A sound coming at you sounds high pitch because the sound wave is compressed. The same sound sounds lower pitch when it's going away from you because the sound wave is stretched. 

Light act the same way, but it's only noticeable at very high speed. Far away galaxies recede from us at nearly the speed of light. Their light is so stretched when it reaches us, it appear infrared, or red shifted. Light coming at you would look bluer or blue shifted. Andromeda galaxy is blue shifted
